title: Sergey Litvinov (athlete, born 1958)
text:
Sergey Nikolaevich Litvinov (; 23 January 1958 – 19 February 2018) was a Russian <a href="hammer%20throw">hammer throw</a>er and <a href="sport%20of%20athletics">athletics</a> coach. He competed at the <a href="1980%20Summer%20Olympics">1980 Summer Olympics</a> and the <a href="1988%20Summer%20Olympics">1988 Summer Olympics</a>, missing the <a href="1984%20Summer%20Olympics">1984 Summer Olympics</a> due to the Soviet boycott, and won a silver and a gold medal, respectively. He also won two <a href="IAAF%20World%20Championships%20in%20Athletics">world titles</a>, in 1983 and 1987. After retiring from competitions he coached elite hammer throwers including <a href="Ivan%20Tsikhan">Ivan Tsikhan</a> and his son <a href="Sergey%20Litvinov%20%28athlete%2C%20born%201986%29">Sergey</a>.
Career.
Throughout his career Litvinov battled with <a href="Yuriy%20Sedykh">Yuriy Sedykh</a>. Litvinov set three world records, the last being 84.14 metres in June 1983. However, Sedykh improved the world record to 86.34 m in 1984 and to 86.74 m at the <a href="1986%20European%20Championships%20in%20Athletics%23Field">1986 European championships</a>. In 1986 Litvinov threw 86.04 metres which remained his personal best. This result puts him second on the all-time performer's list, behind Sedykh. He also coached Ivan Tsikhan.
Litvinov finished second behind Sedykh and ahead of <a href="J%C3%BCri%20Tamm">Jüri Tamm</a> in the <a href="1980%20Summer%20Olympics">1980 Summer Olympics</a>. After missing the <a href="1984%20Summer%20Olympics">1984 Games</a> because of the Soviet boycott, he won the gold in <a href="1988%20Summer%20Olympics">1988</a> ahead of Sedykh; his throw of 84.80 m remains the Olympic record.
Litvinov's son <a href="Sergey%20Litvinov%20%28athlete%2C%20born%201986%29">Sergey</a> is also an elite hammer thrower.
Death.
Litvinov was reported to have died on 19 February 2018 in <a href="Sochi">Sochi</a> at the age of 60. It was reported by Russia's athletics federation that he suddenly fell from his bicycle as he cycled home from a coaching session, and an ambulance crew was unable to revive him.
